content.raw:
Looks good!

In the analysis subprocess, could you also first read in the master lab config file and then the additional one (like we do in the main lyse process). That way we won't get confused in the future if we use labconfig for something else (and don't realise the main one isn't being loaded).

Oh....hmm. I just realised that of course the labconfig **is** loaded, but is done so in `lyse.init`. Where the `_lyse_port` is used, but also cached as the default value for the `port` in the `data` function. This default value (at least in a quick test in a python 2.7 terminal...not on this actual code) doesn't get overridden by your new code, so I think that means the analysis script reads data from the wrong instance? We probably need to convert the reading of the port (in `lyse.__init__` to be lazy again, and then I think it would be better if you used `_labconfig.read(additional_config)` in the analysis\_subprocess.py code.
content.html:
Looks good!

In the analysis subprocess, could you also first read in the master lab config file and then the additional one (like we do in the main lyse process). That way we won't get confused in the future if we use labconfig for something else (and don't realise the main one isn't being loaded).

Oh....hmm. I just realised that of course the labconfig is loaded, but is done so in lyse.init. Where the _lyse_port is used, but also cached as the default value for the port in the data function. This default value (at least in a quick test in a python 2.7 terminal...not on this actual code) doesn't get overridden by your new code, so I think that means the analysis script reads data from the wrong instance? We probably need to convert the reading of the port (in lyse.__init__ to be lazy again, and then I think it would be better if you used _labconfig.read(additional_config) in the analysis_subprocess.py code.

content.raw: You're totally right I think I fixed it now. I also had a namespacing bug that I fixed now everything should work.
content.html: You're totally right I think I fixed it now. I also had a namespacing bug that I fixed now everything should work.

content.raw:
@{557058:cbf1bc43-1dc2-477b-9e25-1a8f40fd7ee3} @{557058:a70cc9cf-684e-4849-a61a-9ade4d7218b5}  This is going to need reworking before we can merge.

I think it’s still a good idea to do, but we need to resolve the merge conflict. I’ve also realised that the line with the conflict \(`process_tree.zlock_client.set_process_name('lyse-'+os.path.basename(filepath))`\) is going to need to use the lyse port included or else it’s going to conflict with scripts with the same name connected to another instance of lyse. I’m not sure what the consequences of that overlap are, but it would be best to correct in case it becomes a problem down the line.

‌

I’ve also realised that the line with the conflict (process_tree.zlock_client.set_process_name('lyse-'+os.path.basename(filepath))) is going to need to use the lyse port included or else it’s going to conflict with scripts with the same name connected to another instance of lyse. I’m not sure what the consequences of that overlap are, but it would be best to correct in case it becomes a problem down the line.

content.raw:
I think I would vote to decline this in favour of having labconfig look for command line options/environment variables \(the main apps could accept command line options, but then they will need to set environment variables for child processes to inherit\) that modify which config file\(s\) to use more generally, that would work for all applications. It doesn’t seem super specific to lyse. So I would vote to close and reopen as a feature request.

If you agree then we could close this and reopen as a feature request.
content.html:
I think I would vote to decline this in favour of having labconfig look for command line options/environment variables (the main apps could accept command line options, but then they will need to set environment variables for child processes to inherit) that modify which config file(s) to use more generally, that would work for all applications. It doesn’t seem super specific to lyse. So I would vote to close and reopen as a feature request.

If you agree then we could close this and reopen as a feature request.

content.raw: Yeah ok. I think it’s also less relevant now that we have good support for virtual environments
